In downtown Dartmouth you’ll find a charming intimate space with world class bartenders and talented cooks. @dearfriendbar has an impressive bottle list, a tasty, yet every changing menu, and a super chill vibe. 

Join Seasoned Plate and Discover Halifax as we explore a range of delicious places to eat and drink throughout the greater Halifax region. You just may discover your new favourite cocktail bar! 

Dear Friend was developed to fill a void in the Downtown Dartmouth landscape. It was opened to provide a place for great cocktails, excellent spirits, and exceptional small plates for the local dining and drinking public. They’ve succeeded in reaching their goal. Their cocktails are some of the best in the city and change with the passing of the seasons. Their space is inviting and safe. Their staff are knowledgeable and have the ability to take patrons on a trip down an unexpected, yet delightful, flavourful journey…

For full review visit www.seasonedplate.ca

In downtown Dartmouth you’ll find a European inspired fine dining establishment with sophisticated plates that highlight local seasonality. @oxalisns is a world class dining experience that is sure to impress. 

Join Seasoned Plate and Discover Halifax as we explore a range of delicious places to eat and drink throughout the greater Halifax region. You just may discover your new favourite fine dining restaurant! 

Oxalis itself is housed in a beautifully restored Nova Scotian home from a bygone era, and they have respectfully paid homage to this space. The two dining areas are devoted to enhancing the overall experience as they create a sense of being exactly where you are meant to be.…

For full review visit www.seasonedplate.ca

Haligonians are no strangers to the rainy weather during the cold months ☔

Halifax is a coastal city situated near where the warm Gulf Stream meets the chilly Labrador Current. As the warm and cold air masses from the ocean form and collide, they create foggy and rainy conditions 🌊🌧️ 

It's no surprise why Halifax sees over 100 days of rain and fog each year!

📍  Angus L. Macdonald Bridge
📷 @riazoozeer

Don't let the chilly weather stop you from exploring the Halifax region 🌊❄️ 

As Peggy's Cove becomes quiet during the winter months, it's the perfect time to wander around the village and catch unspoiled views of the lighthouse. ✨ 

After your stroll, get cozy at @rhubarbrestaurant_, just 5 minutes away. Warm up to a menu full of comfort food, highlighting local seafood and seasonal ingredients. Get festive with their three-course December holiday lunch menu, available during weekdays. 🍴🦞🎄 

Send this to your pals and let them know it's time for a day trip 🚗✨ 

📍 Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia
📷 @kelsie.auralee

#DiscoverHalifax

Behind these wrought iron gates lies the Halifax Public Gardens 🌸🌳 

Formally established in 1867, this urban oasis is the oldest Victorian garden in North America. Stroll through the winding trails of the garden lined with stunning statues, fountains, and 32 geometric flower beds. As you wander through the flora, you'll feel as though you've fallen into a fairytale. 🌲✨ 

From now until January 1, the Halifax Public Gardens will be aglow with a festive trail of holiday lights every evening from 5pm-9pm. Grab a toasty drink from a nearby cafe and explore the glittering gardens after dark for the most magical moonlit experience. 🌙🎄 

📍 Halifax Public Gardens
📷 @photosbymattm

As the sun rises later in the winter months, it's the perfect time to bundle up and catch a glimpse of the fiery sky over the harbour. 🌅🌊 

Tip: For just $2.75, you can hop on the ferry and head over to Downtown Dartmouth. Catch stunning harbour views before you discover an urban village filled with one-of-a-kind shops, adorable cafés and restaurants, and so much more. 🛍️🥐✨

Grab a dose of fresh air with a dash of salt this week at the beach. 🌊✨ 

Cruise out to Crystal Crescent Beach, just 40 minutes outside of Halifax. If you're in the mood for an adventure, set out on a coastal hike along the Pennant Point trail and be rewarded with breathtaking lookouts along the way. You may even be lucky enough to spot some local wildlife, but be sure to keep a safe distance away. 🥾🦊

Not in the mood for a hike? Bundle up, get cozy on the beach, and listen to the gentle waves lapping on the shore. 🌊🧣🧤 

On your way back to Halifax, stop in at @paviacafe for a bite to eat. Warm up to a menu full of paninis, homemade soups, freshly baked treats, specialty coffees, and more for the most perfect ending to your beach excursion. 🥪🍲☕ 

Who are you bringing with you? Tag them in the comments!👇

📷 @horizoneyephotography

Savour the silence of the Halifax waterfront on a grey winter day. ☔❄️ 

When the sky is clear and the temperature rises, the waterfront is filled with vibrant energy, buzzing with locals and visitors. ☀️✨ 

As the temperature cools and precipitation falls, the waterfront becomes still and quiet, leaving those who visit to have all the sights and sounds to themselves. 🌊🌧️

When do you prefer to experience the Halifax waterfront?

Take date night to the next level during Winter Warm-Up. 🥂❄️ 

Cozy up with a collection of shareable dining experiences at @queensmarque for just $49 until January 26. 🍽️✨ 

From @drifthalifax's Atlantic shellfish hodge podge to coq au vin at @cafelunette.hfx, and an indulgent fondue experience at @peacockwinebar.hfx, find the perfect shareable menu at the link in our bio. 🍗🫕✨ 

📷 @teymour_adham 

#DiscoverHalifax

The viewing deck at Peggy's Cove is just as beautiful as it is functional. 🌊✨ 

Designed by award-winning architect, @og_architect, the viewing deck is set into the landscape and fits the shape of the rock, showcasing the real attractions at Peggy’s Cove – the lighthouse, the landscape, and waves.

The viewing deck and railings are made of wood and steel, materials that will last and complement the rugged terrain. The deck’s rail guard is a steel knit pattern, reminiscent of a fishing net, meant to parallel the landscape, almost camouflaged in the rock in order not to overshadow the view.

With such careful thought of the design and accessibility elements, it's no surprise why this viewing deck at Peggy's Cove has received high praise. ⚙️🎨🥇 

📍 Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia
📷 @mazakyphotography

Wind down from the busy week with a refreshing coastal retreat. 🌊👇 

Head out to Polly's Cove for a scenic hike filled with panoramic ocean views, including a unique perspective of the famed Peggy's Point Lighthouse. Wander along the rugged trails sprinkled with glacial erratics at every turn. With crisp coastal air and such striking scenery, you'll wish you could bottle the whole experience to take home. 🌊🥾🌲 

After your hike, head over to @rhubarbrestaurant_, @tasteofns' 2022 Restaurant of The Year for a meal and enjoy the breathtaking views of St. Margaret’s Bay while staying warm from the winter wind. 🍲🍻✨

Step inside @lakecitycider, a light and airy cider taproom nestled in the heart of downtown Dartmouth. 🍎🦆 

With 100% local fruit sourced from the Annapolis Valley, one of Canada’s five main apple-growing regions, it's no question why this cider is considered a “living love letter to Dartmouth”. 🍎❤️✨ 

For a perfect Friday afternoon outing, grab your friends and get cozy in the taproom with a flight of cider and some board games. On select Fridays, Lake City Cider collects a portion of their cider sales and donates the proceeds in support of their local community. Aside from being @thecoasthalifax's Gold Winner of Halifax's Best Cidery of 2022, it's the perfect excuse to check this spot out. 🥇🙌 

Who are you taking here? Tag them in the comments! 👇 

📍 Lake City Cider - 35 Portland St, downtown Dartmouth

Introducing the 2023 Official Halifax Visitor Guide. 🌊 📖 ✨ 

Perfect for locals and visitors alike, this guide highlights the best things to see and do in the Halifax region. From local tips and stories to offbeat itineraries and so much more, flip through to get inspired and plan your next adventure. 🦞🏖️🛍️🎶

This year's guide has been a community effort with contributions from many talented locals, including:

Riaz Oozeer (@riazoozeer), an incredible Mauritius-born photographer whose photos are featured throughout the guide. Riaz also shares his passion for top-notch local cafés through his guide to Halifax's coffee scene on page 34. 📷☕ 

Janna Wilton (@jannawiltonart), a local watercolour artist whose art is scattered throughout the guide and highlighted in "Wildflowers of Nova Scotia" on page 40. 🎨🌼 

Laura Oakley (@halifood), a passionate local freelance food and travel writer. Allow Laura to guide you through the best local spots to get your lobster fix on page 28 and discover Halifax's growing cider scene on page 30. 🦞🍎

Raeesa Lalani (@raester), a multi-talented arts professional and leader of Prismatic Arts Festival. Find Raeesa's inside look at Halifax's underground arts scene on page 36. 🖼️🎶 

Abady Alzharani (@abadya), an artist, entrepreneur, dance educator, and founder of House of Eights Dance Studio. Being a lover of all things local, Abady shares his selection of the best feel-good businesses across the Halifax region on page 32. 🍹💛

Brad Dykema (@brad.dykema), a freelance writer, fitness enthusiast, and armchair urbanist. Find out what makes Peggy's Cove a one-of-a-kind destination from Brad's lens on page 60. 🌊✨ 

We'd like to thank our local partners for their valuable contributions throughout the guide. 💛

Find the digital version of the 2023 Official Halifax Visitor Guide at the link in our bio. 🔗

#DiscoverHalifax

There's something to be said about quiet foggy nights in the city. 🌙☁️✨ 

Have you ever wondered why this city is so foggy? 
Halifax is situated near where the warm Gulf Stream meets the chilly Labrador Current. As the warm and cold air masses from the ocean form and collide, they create foggy and rainy conditions. 🌊🌧️

It's no surprise why Halifax sees over 100 days of rain and fog each year. ☔✨ 

📍 Historic Properties, downtown Halifax
📷 @shaun_d_simpson 

#DiscoverHalifax

Wildfires across the Halifax region are now 100% contained as we move into the recovery phase of this difficult time.

Some of our region’s tourism operators are in various stages of reopening. The community spirit among Haligonians has been inspiring, and we’ve seen local businesses come together to offer everything from free hair washing (@spiritspahfx) to free clothing (@theloothfx), to things for kids to do (@discoverycentrehalifax), and businesses offering free places to charge devices (@labourdaypicnic, among others) for those displaced from their homes.  

We’d like to thank the Halifax Regional Fire & Emergency and all first responders for their incredible efforts during this time. 

A few updates from Halifax:
🔥 Open fires are not permitted anywhere in the province. The ban includes campfires/bonfires in all parks and campgrounds (provincial or private). It also applies to backyard campfires, brush burning, and fireworks.

🚌 Halifax Transit bus Route 330 will return to regular service on Monday, June 5. 

🌲 Municipal parks and trails – except those in areas with evacuation orders in place – are re-opened as of Monday, June 5. 

📞 If you plan on visiting a local business, call ahead or check online to ensure that they are open and operating. 

 📣 For updates from Halifax and Nova Scotia follow @hfxmoments and @nsgov.

📷️ @riazoozeer

Have you ever been to the @bikeandbean? 🚲☕✨ 

Step inside this charming café and bike shop located in the historic French Village Train Station that dates back to the early 1900s. Sit down to a menu filled with oven-fresh baked treats, specialty coffees, wraps and paninis, daily soups, salads, and all-day breakfast. Choose to dine inside or outside on the sunny patio, or take your treats to-go on a cycling adventure. 🍪🥪🥑 

Situated along the scenic 33km St. Margaret’s Bay Area Rails-to-Trails, the @bikeandbean is the ultimate day trip destination. Rent a bike from the shop, grab your picnic lunch from the café, and treat yourself to some of the most stunning elevated panoramic views of St. Margaret’s Bay. 🌊🚲🌳✨ 

📍 Train Station Bike & Bean - 5401 St. Margaret's Bay Rd
📷 @snackingandsipping

#DiscoverHalifax

Halifax’s salty breeze and warm charm are calling. From waterfront strolls to the vibrant local scene, Halifax is a true Atlantic gem.

🍴Culinary🥂

Halifax’s culinary scene will suit everyone’s tastes. Step into @hfxbrewerymarket, a 200-year-old building filled with local artisans - a quintessential autumn experience. If you’re a fan of craft beverages, look no further than @goodcheertrail, which has over 90 different stops!! And, for an authentic Nova Scotian experience, take a seat at @thenarrowshalifaxpub, where you’ll find a cozy space filled with all kinds of old curiosities.

🌱Green Spaces🌲

To really see the city, take a stroll along Halifax’s waterfront, with an accessible boardwalk lined with harbours, shops, art, and restaurants. We also suggest visiting @hfxpublicgardens, the only true Victorian-style garden in North America. Finally, a trip to the East Coast would not be complete without visiting a lighthouse, take some time to visit Nova Scotia’s famous Peggy’s Cove Lighthouse

🎨Arts & Culture🎭

Halifax is bursting with public art. Throughout its neighbourhoods you’ll find unique murals scattered, many within walking distance. You can also learn more about Canadian artist Maud Lewis, whose house is actually a part of a permanent gallery alongside her work.

🛶Indigenous Experiences🦅

The Halifax Regional Municipality is located in Mi'kma'ki, the ancestral and traditional lands of the Mi'kmaq people. We suggest visiting the @ns_mma for the ‘Ta'n me'j Tel-keknuo'ltiek: How Unique We Still Are’ exhibit, which offers a platform for Mi’kmaw people to express their continued experiences.

📜History and Heritage🏛️

There’s no better place to immerse yourself in maritime history than the Maritime Museum of the Atlantic. From small craft boat building to World War Convoys and the Titanic, you’ll discover stories and people that have defined Nova Scotia and its relationship with the sea. We also suggest the @halifaxcitadel, a National Historic Site with some of the best views of the city.

Fog-cloaked days in Halifax seem to add a little mystery to the city’s history. ☁️✨ 

Do you know the history behind Halifax’s Old Town Clock?👇 
In 1800, Prince Edward, Duke of Kent, was preparing to return to England. Obsessed with punctuality, the Commander-in-Chief of the British military made a parting gift to Halifax: a town clock on the hill overlooking Brunswick Street. This way, he could ensure the city’s forces were always on time. 🎁⚔️🕰️ 

Today, it continues to keep all who live in Halifax on time, just as it has for generations. 🕰️🙌

📍 Old Town Clock - Brunswick St, downtown Halifax
📷 @camillepapote

On the southern tip of the Halifax peninsula sits Point Pleasant Park, a tranquil escape just minutes from the city’s downtown core. 🌊🌲🍂 

Comprising 185 acres of forest, trails, beaches, monuments, and military fortifications, the park has a rich history and has been an essential landmark for hundreds of years. 🐦‍⬛🪼✨

This park was once a significant Mi’kmaq gathering place known as Amntu’kati (“spiritual place” or “the place of spirits”), then served as an important British defensive site in part of the Halifax Defence Complex, where numerous fortifications and batteries were constructed to guard the entrance to the harbour. 🪶⚔️

Fun fact: Since the late 19th century, the park has been leased from the British government at the cost of 1 shilling per year. 🪙

If you haven’t strolled the winding trails of Point Pleasant Park, this is your sign to go. 🌊☀️✨ 

📍 Point Pleasant Park, Nova Scotia
📷 @ashleyydawnxo

#DiscoverHalifax

You won’t have to stroll far to notice that Halifax is home to a number of old cemeteries. 🪦🌙

While cemeteries can be seen as somewhat ambiguous spaces, they offer a window into some of Halifax’s history. Established in 1844, Camp Hill Cemetery is one of Halifax’s most notable burying grounds and is the final resting place of Alexander Keith and Viola Desmond, among many other historical Halifax figures. 

Wander through the grounds, sheltered by towering linden, elm, and chestnut trees and notice how the sounds of the street fade into the background. You might be surprised by how peaceful a place like this can be. 🐦‍⬛🌳✨ 

📍 Camp Hill Cemetery - 1600 Summer St
📷 @globesnappeur

Bundle up and make your way down to the Halifax waterfront to catch @evergreenfestns in full holiday glow for its final weekend. 🎄❄️✨ 

Here’s what you’ll find at this magical seaside festival:

- A market with vendors from across the province offering a variety of local food, drink, apparel, gifts, and more. (Open during select hours Thursday- Sunday) ☕🛍️

- A walkable outdoor trail of twinkling holiday light displays and installations along the Halifax waterfront, throughout downtown Halifax, downtown Dartmouth, and beyond. 🌙✨

- Free, family-friendly live music at @thebghalifax with festive treats and toasty drinks. (Open during select hours Friday - Sunday) 🎤🎶

- A winter sports zone filled with fun games, including live broadcasting of the @hfx_mooseheads games. (Open during select hours Friday - Sunday) 🥌🏒

And more. 🎄✨

@evergreenfestns is on until December 17. Find out everything you need to know about it at the link in our bio. 🔗

Haligonians are no strangers to the rainy weather during the cold months. ☔❄️ 

Halifax is a coastal city situated near where the warm Gulf Stream meets the chilly Labrador Current. As the warm and cold air masses from the ocean form and collide, they create foggy and rainy conditions. 🌊🌧️

It’s no surprise why Halifax sees over 100 days of rain and fog each year. 📆☁️✨

Peggy’s Cove is a place where nature wears its emotions on its sleeve. 🌊🌬️✨ 

With brooding clouds and crashing waves, the rugged landscapes of this fishing village come alive with raw, untamed beauty. These moody days reveal the hidden charm that flourishes in the unpredictable Atlantic weather. 🌊🌧️✨ 

While it’s strongly advised against venturing out to the coast in stormy weather, there are ways to safely take in the spectacle of the dramatic elements.👇 

@oceanstoneseasideresort offers a Storm Watch package, perfect for getting warm and cozy with front-row seats to approaching storms in a waterfront cottage. Paired with craft beer and a charcuterie board for two, there’s no better way to take in the rugged charm of a storm in Peggy’s Cove. 🏠🧀🍻 

📍 Peggy’s Cove, Nova Scotia
📷 @shelleywyman
